awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Engineering of Recoverable Cellulosomes for Bioconversion
awd_abstract_narration:
The sustainable, industrial-scale production of transportation biofuels from plant biomass rely on enzymes called cellulases that break down the cellulosic fraction of biomass into sugars that can be fermented into bioethanol.  The major cost of this process is the cellulase, which in the current generation of cellulosic biofuel facilities, is discarded after use because it must be dissolved in water to break down cellulose to sugars, and cannot be easily recovered.  Recycling the cellulase enzyme would reduce the cost of cellulosic biofuels production.  The goal of this project is to develop a new way of encapsulating the cellulase enzyme in recoverable solid form so that it can be collected reused multiple times before disposal. The key innovation is to bind the cellulase enzyme to nanometer-sized capsule called a cellulosome, which preserves the activity of the enzyme for cellulose conversion, and has a magnetic core which facilitates its recovery from dilute water processing streams.  The educational activities associated with this project include mentoring of undergraduate student projects coordinated through the Nurturing American Tribal Undergraduate Research and Education (NATURE) program at North Dakota State University.

Microorganisms that naturally produce cellulase enzymes bind them into special structures on the cell surface called cellulosomes.  Due to the close proximity of these enzymes within the cellulosomes, the bioconversion of cellulosic and hemicellulosic materials proceeds with a high velocity and efficiency.   However, in the industrial production of celluloytic enzymes, the cellulosome is not present.  This research will engineer recoverable cellulosomes through a biomimetic approach where celluloytic enzymes are encapsulated within a nanstructured capsule containing a magnetic core.  This biomimetic cellulosome will contain a number of complimentary celluloytic enzymes confined within a polymeric environment, and will be engineered to mimic several key properties of natural cellulosomes, including diversity of hydrolytic activity, close proximity of complementary enzymes, and strong and selective binding of the biomimetic cellulosome to cellulosic substrates.  The magnetic core of the biomimetic cellulosome will facilitate its recovery from liquid suspension using magnetic separation techniques.   To explore the potential of the biomimetic cellulosome for biomass conversion processes, the research has four objectives. The first objective is to make a series of new biomimetic cellulosomes to enhance synergism of hydrolytic enzymes for bioconversion of cellulosic materials to sugars.  The second objective is to quantify the effects of the biomimetic cellulosome structure and immobilized enzyme diversity on cellulose hydrolysis to gain a fundamental understanding of cellulase synergism in natural cellulosomes.  The third objective is to gain a fundamental understanding of cellulosome interaction with cellulosic substrates and lignin, and the fourth objective is to augment the functionality of the biomimetic cellulosome for broader applications.   The anticipated outcomes from these studies include a fundamental understanding of the synergism of enzymes in engineered cellulosomes, their efficacy for different forms of substrates, and their potential for recovery and reuse.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to improve the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass into sugars for the production of biofuels and bioproducts. Currently, a substantial fraction of the biorefinery costs is due to the production of cellulases, which are enzymes that depolymerize cellulose into glucose. Cellulosomes are multienzyme complexes that combine a multitude of different enzymes (cellulases, hemicellulases, carbohydrate-binding modules) that work in concert more efficiently than a mixture of the same free enzyme consortia to synergistically degrade plant biomass. Our efforts were focused on the development of biomimetic synthetic polymer-enzyme complexes that mimic natural cellulosomes - biological molecular machines. Applications of such complexes could improve the efficiency of the use of cellulases in biofuel production.

Intellectual merit

Precisely organized multienzyme complexes are very useful to identify the role and contributions of different proteins and their spatial arrangements on the synergistic performance of biocatalytic systems, in this case, biomimetic cellulosomes. In this project, randomly mixed and defined enzyme complexes were synthesized and characterized. The biological synthesis of well-organized complexes is costly, labor extensive, and difficult to scale up; however, the construction of random biomimetic cellulosomes is much less expensive and readily scalable.

We generated precisely arranged cellulosome structures using DNA scaffolds. This design scheme allows us to define enzyme position and arrangements based on specific DNA sequences (motifs) that were complementary to the DNA oligonucleotides used to label different enzymes. The enzymes were conjugated to the DNA scaffolds in a predefined order and arrangement based on complementary base pairing. The results demonstrated that the synergistic performance of such cellulosomes is very sensitive to the type of enzymes and their arrangement around the carbohydrate-binding modules that facilitate binding of the complex to the cellulose substrates.

In contrast, random cellulosome structures were prepared using statistical copolymers of poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate and glycidyl methacrylate. Epoxy groups of the glycidyl methacrylate monomeric units were covalently linked to the enzymes via amino-functional groups of surface lysine residues. The complexes were prepared via mixing of the copolymeric scaffolds with a blend of cellulase enzymes. The experiments demonstrated that the random complexes demonstrated substantial synergistic performance at low enzyme-to substrate ratios when less than 50% of cellulose substrate is occupied by the enzymes. The important and interesting result is that a mixture of the random complex with free enzymes in solution demonstrated even greater synergistic activity. Taken together, these results demonstrated that there is no need for separation and purification of the complexes when the mixture of enzymes and copolymeric scaffold could be applied directly for use in cellulose conversion.

 Furthermore, we demonstrated that poly(ethylene glycol) fragments provide a stabilizing function for enzymes. Using computer simulations and model experimental systems, it was demonstrated that poly(ethylene glycol) –protein interactions are improved by elevating the temperature, resulting in both less protein aggregation and loss of the secondary structure. The stabilizing effect was observed for covalently bound poly(ethylene glycol) or just added to enzyme solutions at concentrations close or above critical overlap concentration in solution.

Broader impact

Our findings open new directions for the design of biocatalytic refineries with improved efficiency using synthetic polymer additives. In addition, our results suggest that this technology can be readily applied to other complex biocatalytic systems for green biomanufacturing processes of the future. This project catalyzed interdisciplinary, international collaborations between the University of Georgia, North Dakota State University, Clemson University, Brookhaven National Lab, and the Institute for Condensed Matter Physics in Ukraine. This interdisciplinary and cultural environment added to the education and research experience of 4 graduate students and two undergraduate students at the University of Georgia (UGA). The students participated in all stages of the project, from the first experiments and presentation of results to the preparation and publication of peer-reviewed manuscripts. This training also drove the development of hands-on technical skills in different areas of modern science and technology, including protein expression, designing DNA sequences for protein conjugation, synthesis of functional polymers, analyzing protein stability and biocatalytic activity, analyses of computer simulations and data, pretreatment of biomass, and depolymerization of biomass. One UGA student participated in a six-month NSF training program and performed hands-on research at Brookhaven National Lab.
